keyTerms.definition: A foreign individual, entity, trust, or government connected to a discriminatory foreign country as defined in §899(b)(1). Includes non‑U.S. individuals tax‑resident in that country; foreign corporations resident there (unless U.S.-owned CFCs); foreign corporations >50 % owned by such persons; certain trusts; branches; and other entities Treasury may specify.
Any foreign jurisdiction that imposes one or more *unfair foreign taxes* within the meaning of §899(d)(1). Treasury will list qualifying countries in quarterly guidance.

A foreign tax regime that disproportionately burdens U.S. persons, including an Undertaxed Profits Rule (UTPR), Digital Services Tax (DST), Diverted Profits Tax (DPT), or other extraterritorial/discriminatory taxes identified by Treasury. See §899(c)(1).

The first day of the first calendar year beginning on or after the latest of (i) 90 days after enactment of §899, (ii) 180 days after the unfair tax is enacted, or (iii) the date the unfair tax begins to apply. Rate surcharges ramp from this date. §899(a)(4)(C).
The rate‑increase factor applied to specified U.S. tax rates on payments to applicable persons. Year 1: +5 pp; each anniversary: additional +5 pp; capped at +20 pp. §899(a)(4)(A)–(B).

A minimum tax on certain large corporations that make deductible payments to foreign related parties (§59A). §899(a)(2) modifies BEAT rules for corporations connected to discriminatory countries, raising the rate to 12.5 % and removing key exceptions.
A top‑up tax under OECD Pillar Two that allocates residual tax liability to entities in jurisdictions where group income is undertaxed. Listed as an ‘unfair foreign tax’ in §899(c)(1).

A gross‑basis tax on digital advertising, marketplace, or user‑interface revenues, typically imposed on non‑resident tech companies (e.g., France 3 %, UK 2 %). Identified as an unfair foreign tax in §899(c)(1).
A tax that targets perceived profit‑shifting by multinationals (e.g., UK DPT 25 %). Explicitly treated as an unfair foreign tax in §899(c)(1).
A foreign tax determined by reference to income or profits of entities outside the taxing country, other than by direct ownership. See §899(c)(2).
A tax that meets any of the criteria in §899(c)(3), such as applying chiefly to non‑residents or being levied on a base other than net income without cost recovery.
Gains and losses on U.S. real‑property interests recognized by a non‑resident and taxed as effectively connected income under §897(a). Relevant for the §899(a)(1)(C) limitation.
The depreciable tangible‑asset base used in calculating a routine return under GILTI and BEAT. §899(a)(2) eliminates QBAI relief for affected taxpayers.
A U.S. tax credit for foreign income taxes. It is presently uncertain whether §899 surcharges will be creditable; Treasury guidance is anticipated.
Temporary relief under §899(a)(5)(D): no penalties or interest on failures to withhold before 1 Jan 2027 if best efforts are demonstrated.
The incremental rate increase applied to specified U.S. income and withholding taxes payable by or attributable to applicable persons from discriminatory countries.

acronyms.expansion: Foreign Investment in Real Property Tax Act

relatedLegislation.description: Base Erosion and Anti‑Abuse Tax (BEAT); modified by §899(a)(2).
U.S. withholding tax rules on U.S.‑source FDAP income; rates increased for applicable persons.
FIRPTA regime on U.S. real‑property interests; §899 increases withholding under §1445.
Global minimum‑tax framework introducing UTPR, expressly targeted by §899.
International negotiations on digital‑services taxation relevant to unfair‑tax designation.
